text:
Sawadee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today I 
am making a popular Thai Street food that happens

to also be vegetarian I'm making something 
called tao huh tod tao hu means tofu and

Tod means deep-fried so it's crispy fried tofu 
and it comes with a sweet chili peanut dipping

sauce uh if you're thinking I'm not a tofu person 
just hang in there because the sauce is good on

deep-fried anything let's get started this sauce 
is similar to that sweet chili dipping sauce that

you see on girls restore shelves but it is so 
much better and so worth the time I'm going to

start out with some pretty file or spur Chili's 
which are these big mild ish Thai Chili's you

can also substitute other types of red Chili's 
or bell peppers if you want it not spicy at all

and yes it's frosty because I freeze these and 
all this is just gonna go into the blender and

I'm also going to throw in a clove of garlic and 
now all the liquid I've got some water and just

some white vinegar in Thailand the only kind of 
vinegar that we use is actually white vinegar we

don't have all sorts of fancy different types of 
vinegar like here in North America and I'm going

to add another source of acid that's going to 
add a little extra dimension and that is tamarind

okay and now I'm just going to get that into a 
pot alright so we've got all our assets are sour

in this pot now the sweet granulated sugar to 
add a little bit of a caramely flavor i'm going

to add some chopped palm sugar and of course 
a little bit of salt just to bring everything

together i'm going to let this come to a simmer 
and let it simmer for a few minutes just until

it's thick and has that dipped consistency so it's 
been simmering for a few minutes and you want to

kill the heat just when it's still a little bit 
too runny because as it cools it will thicken up

a little bit so the sauce is cooled down and so 
I like this consistency see it's thick and Dibble

perfect now I'm going to taste it and see if I 
need to adjust it mmm hmmm okay I'm going to go

in with a little bit more vinegar now it's time to 
finish it off with first of all some chili flakes

okay now you cook just add some fresh Thai chilies 
and blend it all up a little bit of spicy good and

peanuts make it even more viscous little stay on 
the tofu and it also balances out the tartness

you can add more or less peanuts completely up to 
you and if you're allergic to nuts you can also

try ground sesame seeds cilantro some chopped 
up cilantro now I wouldn't add the cilantro

until you're ready to serve okay cuz otherwise 
it'll just wilt and not look great now oh that

looks good and it smells really good now alright 
so here's the sauce here's my tofu which I've

cut into triangles so I am using firm tofu okay 
because that's traditionally what we use because

it's Street food it's finger food so soft tofu is 
not going to hold very well also firm tofu will

fry up crispy ER around the edges I'm also going 
to salt my tofu a little bit and this is just my

trick they don't do this but I find that if the 
tofu itself has some seasoning its him year after

salting I just let the salt sort of sit there for 
a few minutes so that it dissolves on the surface

of the tofu I've got my oil here heating up and 
you want this at about 375 a little hotter than

normal tofu likes to travel to earth each other 
and they may stick to each other that's okay let

them stick for a while don't hurry up and and 
pull them apart because you'll tear them so let

them firm up a little bit once they are firm on 
the outside then you can pull them apart okay so

give them a minute or so and you could stir them 
and keep them moving to prevent them from sticking

to each other but careful because it likes to 
stick to your tongs as well so I'm just going

to go for a light golden brown if I fry them for 
too long you're going to dry out the tofu more and

more and more so here they are nice and golden and 
crispy around the edges in case you're wondering

what happened to bu soft tofu I fried some up this 
isn't super soft tofu it's sort of medium soft

tofu and so what happens is as you can see they 
get a little bit wrinkly because there's so much

water and the water leaves the tofu and then so 
it shrinks and wrinkles and also it's not crispy

if you want to fry soft tofu you want to coat it 
in breadcrumbs or some sort of a breading on the

outside like when they make a kadosh eat tofu then 
the coating will protect the tofu then the coating

gets brown and crispy and the soft tofu inside 
gets protected now we eat this as a snack in

Thailand sort of you know the three o'clock snack 
but it's a great dish to serve as an appetizer

at a party your all your vegetarian friends 
will be happy there you go and add a little

extra peanuts on top just to you know represent 
what's inside also a little extra cilantro ah

so good you've got sort of the crispy edges 
but it's also chewy on the outside and soft

on the inside and the the sweet tartness of 
the dipping sauce with that a little bit of

spiciness from the roasted chili flakes oh my god 
this is one of those things where you just you

just can't stop eating so the next time you've 
got some friends over and you're looking for an

appetizer that's different with a bit of zing make 
some thought oh and as I said this dipping sauce

good on deep fried anything so the recipe is on 
hot Thai Kitchen comm if you make this send me

a photo and send it to me on Facebook Twitter or 
Instagram and I will see you next time for your

next delicious Thai meal and so there they are 
nice and golden and crispy around the edges now
